Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineering of III-Nitride Quantum Heterostructures Doped with Lanthanides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: The research component of this CAREER award is to study low-dimensional quantum structures of group-III nitride materials doped with rare-earth ions. The research includes materials characterization using optical, electrical, magnetic, and pressure stimulus, comprehensive modeling, as well as molecular beam epitaxy and pulsed-laser deposition growth in collaboration with other scientists on and off the Ohio University campus. The energy transfer processes between rare-earth ions and III-N hosts and rare-earth ion-defects formation and their nature are the main factors contributing to the quantum efficiency, ferromagnetism, and electronic transport of this materials system. The project investigates approaches to significantly increase radiative quantum yield. Strategies such as modification of the rare-earth ion center environment, through engineering stress/strain parameters during the materials growth process, and localization of carriers in the vicinity of emitting rare-earth ion center, by using quantum structures, are employed. The fundamental atomic level mechanisms and phenomena coupled with synthesis and material processing affecting luminescence, energy excitation processes, and local site symmetry of rare-earth impurities are studied in the project.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. The development of new materials is important to the future needs of semiconductor industries. The project, if successful, can have impacts on the advancement of photonics. The research and education activities of the project are integrated. The central theme of the education activities is to develop photonic curriculum in the PI's department at Ohio University. New photonic courses and laboratories are designed to allow active engagement of undergraduate and graduate students in solving real-world problems. In addition, the outreach component of the project provides intellectual opportunities and stimulation for secondary school and pre-engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the structural, optical and magnetic properties studies of lanthanides, known as rare earth (RE) ions, doped III-nitride (III-N) low-dimensional semiconductor structures. The interest in such materials and resulting devices stems from both fundamental and practical applications in optoelectronics, spintronics and energy conversion. The award was motivated by the prospective applications enabled by these materials which are currently finding in technology and the opportunity to contribute to the understanding of basic science. The primary focus was on the innovative materials growth at a fundamental atomic level, post-growth characterization and comprehensive theoretical modeling of the novel RE ions doped III-N semiconductors quantum structures. The award enabled research comprised of the systematic experimental and theoretical studies of these materials. The specific aim was to asses and in-depth understand the fundamental physics and light emitting devices engineering principles relevant to RE-doped GaN, AlN, InN and their alloys for improving their energy efficiency. The project contributed to developing the needed knowledge to tackle critical issues relevant to growth and engineering RE-doped III-N semiconductors low dimensional quantum structures. Moreover, the project was truly interdisciplinary in nature and engaged experts from U.S. and abroad who participated in scientific and engineering efforts needed for achieving the award goals.

Products of this project includes: (1) development of experimental facility at Ohio University for studying light emission, magnetization and morphology of RE-doped materials, (2) designing and modeling of the RE-doped III-N semiconductors, (3) conducting epitaxial growth of layered RE-doped III-N semiconductors quantum structures, and (4) performing characterization of developed materials and structures under optical, magnetic, temperature and hydrostatic pressure stimuli. In particular, the award’s products numerous journal publications and presentations at national and international conferences, one book chapter and frequent coverage in online e-newsletters and local press. Additional dissemination occurred via supporting undergraduate students’ projects, sponsoring graduate students’ degree projects and students’ industrial training and internships.  

The broad scientific issues addressed by the award formed the fabric of the future research on RE-doped materials at Ohio University. The broader impact of the grant includes societal implications of developing novel materials for civil and military applications contributing to further development of optoelectronic and spintronic technologies. In addition, to specific scientific products, this grant has made several broader contributions to society and beyond. In particular, the impact of the conducted educational and research activities is related to training of students researchers, development of new materials and advance theories for rapidly evolving research field of RE doping materials and exploration of their potential to the future needs of optoelectronics, photonic and spintronic industries. In particular, this award enabled students to directly benefit from the developed curriculum preparing them for participation in rapidly changing novel technologies workforce in the U.S. and abroad. An integral part of the conducted efforts was to train undergraduate and graduate students in solving real-world engineering problems relevant to photonics, spintronics and energy conversion.

The outreach component of the grant provided intellectual opportunities and stimulation for secondary school and pre-engineering students within the South-East Appalachian region of the U.S. participating in college research programs and research activities enables by the award. The final award outcome was the integration of research and education through the training of students and educating the public in a fundamentally and technologically significant area of wide bandgap semiconductors and their applications.
